results.name: Sturmian word: limit S(infinity) where S(0) = 0, S(1) = 0,1 and for n>=1, S(n+1) = S(n)S(n)S(n-1).
comment: This sequence corresponds to the case k = 1 of the Sturmian word S_k(infinity) as defined in A080764. See A171588 for the case k = 2. - _Peter Bala_, Nov 22 2013
This sequence is the {1->01}-transform of the Sturmian word A080764.  - _Clark Kimberling_, May 17 2017

formula: If we read the sequence as the decimal constant C = 0.01010 01010 01010 10010 10010 ... then C = sum {n >= 1} 1/10^floor(n*(1 + sqrt(2))).

The real number 9*C has the simple continued fraction expansion [0; 11, 1010, 10000100, 100000000000100000, 100000000000000000000000000001000000000000, ...], the partial quotients having the form 10^Pell(n)*(1 + 10^Pell(n+1)) = 10^A001333(n+1) + 10^A000129(n) (see Adams and Davison).

A rapidly converging series for C is C = 9*sum {n >= 1} 10^Pell(2*n-1)*(1 + 10^Pell(2*n))/( (10^Pell(2*n-1) - 1)*(10^Pell(2*n+1) - 1) ): for example, the first 10 terms of the series give a rational approximation to C accurate to more than 130 million decimal places. Compare with the Fibonacci words A005614 and A221150. (End)
xref: See A188037 for another version of this sequence. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 22 2011
